Comment: Hi everyone - I have had some fascination for the Ponziani opening ever since a 1200  player played it against me in my previous annotated game A Ponziani Opening.  My opponent gave me the opportunity to transpose into it - things did not work out though.

8. b4? - this pawn push was made in one of the illustrative games from the database - it strikes out at the flank and allows Frere Lenoir to come out on b7 or a6.  In hindsight though I should have castled first.  It will be a long time before I have the opportunity to castle short and by then it was all too late!

8. ......... Nf4 - nasty, nasty, attacks g pawn and prevents castling short because my bishop will be en prise - if I play g2 then black may move his bishop to h3.  If I then exchange bishops my castled position will be very weak should I choose to put Henry on g1.  Reluctantly I put my development into reverse gear and perhaps play Bb2 next move to prepare for long castling - but .....

12. Qd1 - again reverse development to prevent the Wicked Witch of the West from implanting herself on c2.
12. Qd1 - again reverse development to prevent the Wicked Witch of the West from implanting herself on c2.
13. Bb2 - Frere Lenoir develops at last!
13. Bb2 - Frere Lenoir develops at last!

22. ......... Bc2 - nasty, nasty, but little do I know that this will be the beginning of an entrapment for my rook on f1.  Black's bishop pair will become extremely strong as you will soon see.

28. .......... Be2 - here I decide to throw in the sponge.  Although I will only be an exchange down  after Rg1, BxB, KxB black's rook is very strong and I feel I have no counterplay and my opponent has a rating of nearly 200 points north of mine.  The game was unrated so my rating was unaffected.  I hope you have had a good read.  Joanne
